doc.field: The Sopo Archangels (Arcángeles de Sopó) is a famous collection of oil paintings from the Colombian colonial period which is located in the Church of the Divine Savior in the Colombian municipality of Sopó. This art collection has an important historic value. The Archangels are believed to be painted around 1650, but the artist remains unknown. Some art experts believe that the paintings are from Baltasar de Figueroa, others point to the Ecuadorian painter Miguel de Santiago. A third theory indicates the Bogotan painter Bernabe de Posadas. The national Ministry of Culture and the Board of Colonial Art developed a restoration program for the pieces, which have various degrees of damage. Twelve canvas of 2.38 x 1.67 meters depict eleven archangels, plus the Guardian Angel. Each piece contains the Hebraic name of the angel and the Spanish language description: Arielsopo. jpg Ariel – Command of God: The archangel of divine war Baraquel. jpg Baraquel – Blessing of God: The archangel of virtue Custodiosopo. jpg Guardian Angel – Company of God: The angel of children Esriel. jpg Esriel – Justice of God: The archangel of divine discipline Gabrielsopo. jpg Gabriel – Strength of God: The archangel of divine salvation Jehudielsopo. jpg Jehudiel – Penance of God: The archangel of divine hope Laruelsopo. jpg Laruel – Mercy of God: Angel of Mercy Lehadsopo. jpg Leadh – The sun of justice. (Severely damaged. ) Miguelsopo. jpg Michael – Who is like God?: The divine triumph against evil Rafaelsopo. jpg Rafael – Medicine from God: The divine healing Seactielsopo. jpg Seactiel – Pray of God: Angel of divine serenity Urielsopo. jpg Uriel – Fire of God: The divine wrath

The Sopo Archangels (Arcángeles de Sopó) is a famous collection of oil paintings from the Colombian colonial period which is located in the Church of the Divine Savior in the Colombian municipality of Sopó. This art collection has an important historic value. The Archangels are believed to be painted around 1650, but the artist remains unknown. Some art experts believe that the paintings are from Baltasar de Figueroa, others point to the Ecuadorian painter Miguel de Santiago.
